docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration's announcement on Monday that it will strengthen the warning label for the drug RU-486, known by the brand name Mifeprex and often called the French abortion pill, is a case of too little too late. Three Americans have died after taking the pill since it was approved, during a heavily politicized process by Congress and the Clinton administration, in September 2000. The new announcement suggests that the F.D.A. still hasn't learned its lesson -- and that this drug should be taken off the pharmacy shelves. The story of how RU-486 got approval is buried in 9,300 pages of documents released by the drug agency to the legal watchdog group Judicial Watch, which filed a Freedom of Information Act suit. These documents show that the Clinton administration -- which had been warned of the drug's potential hazards as far back as 1995 in a citizen petition filed by Americans United for Life -- pushed to get RU-486 approved before the 2000 election despite the lack of reliable data demonstrating its safety.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Donna J Harrison, obstetrician-gynecologist, contends FDA's announcement that it will strenghthen warning label for drug RU-486, known by brand name Mifeprex, is case of too little too late; notes three Americans have died after taking pill since it was approved in heavily politicized process by Congress and Clinton administration in Sept 2000; contends new announcement suggests that FDA still hasn't learned its lesson--that that this drug should be taken off pharmacy shelves; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration's announcement that it will strengthen the warning label for the drug RU-486 suggests it still hasn't learned its lesson.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a typical night in the maternity ward of this city's second biggest hospital and the loneliest place is the nursery. Empty baby beds are lined up against a wall like rental cars in an airport parking lot. A colorful mobile hangs hopefully over the still room. With more than 1,000 beds, a team of doctors and midwives but only a few births a day, the Frankfurt-Höchst hospital has an abundance of everything except babies.

headline.main: Empty Maternity Wards Imperil a Dwindling Germany

docs.abstract: Germany's falling birthrate is entering its second generation, with dwindling number of potential mothers failing to have enough children to reproduce population; reunification with eastern Germany, where birthrate is even lower than in west, has made matters worse; nation is running out of people it needs to sustain its advanced social systems and public infrastructure; low birthrate is rippling through society in unlikely ways, including sparking competition among hospitals for maternity patients; population experts note even Turkish and other immigrants tend to adapt to national birthrate of 1.3 children per couple within generation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Germany's falling birthrate, like that in much of Western Europe, is entering its second generation.

docs.lead_paragraph: 'Banishing Verona' By Margot Livesey 321 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $24. Man and woman meet. Man and woman, through complications and misunderstandings, lose each other. Man and woman, through more complications, find each other again. Or don't. A reviewer is not supposed to say. What this reviewer will say is that the story line in ''Banishing Verona'' is one of fiction's four or five classic chestnuts. And that Margot Livesey, though British, has whipped hers into the airborne delicacy known to the French as a Mont Blanc. Use the finest ingredients, the French advise, and Ms. Livesey has. Lace it with a curious home-distilled intoxicant; the French probably wouldn't, but Ms. Livesey certainly has.

headline.main: Overalls Nailed to the Floor And Other Puzzles of Love

docs.abstract: Richard Eder reviews book Banishing Verona by Margot Livesey; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The story line in Margot Livesey's new novel is one of fiction's four or five classic chestnuts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two More Resignations at the C.I.A. The head of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service and his deputy resigned, becoming the most significant casualties of an effort by the new director, Porter J. Goss, to overhaul spying operations. PAGE A12 Deficit Doubles in a Year At Insurer of Pensions The federal agency that insures pension plans said its deficit doubled in its last fiscal year, to $23.3 billion, partially because of airline industry failures. In addition, the agency's director called on Congress to address the situation quickly so that it does not spiral out of control. PAGE C1 Iran Agrees to Nuclear Deal France, Britain and Germany announced an accord with Iran committing it to freeze a critical part of its nuclear program. PAGE A3 McGreevey Steps Down Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey ended his tenure quietly as his successor, Richard J. Codey, prepared to replace him. PAGE B1 Another Honor for Bonds Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants was voted most valuable player in the National League for the seventh time in his career. PAGE D1 Giants Give Manning a Shot The Giants, who lost three of their last four games, said the rookie quarterback Eli Manning would start Sunday against Atlanta. PAGE D1 Warning on Abortion Pill ederal drug regulators strengthened the warning label on the abortion pill, RU-486, after the death of a woman who took the pill. Doctors are being reminded to watch for systemic bacterial infection, vaginal bleeding and tubal pregnancy. PAGE A24 Meet the Beatles! Again Capitol Records has issued on CD the first four Beatles albums released in the United States, all from 1964. Previous CD's had British versions of the early albums. PAGE E1

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The appendix, a vestigial organ that people seem able to live very well without, is also one of the most distressing and costly parts of the human body. With little or no warning, the appendix can become obstructed and infected, making appendicitis the most common cause for emergency surgery in Western countries. Even though the incidence of appendicitis has declined significantly since the 1930's, about 250,000 cases still occur each year in the United States. Appendicitis can afflict people of all ages, from infants to the elderly. In Western countries, 9 percent of men and 7 percent of women will develop appendicitis.

headline.main: A Superfluous Organ Can Still Cause Trouble

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on appendicitis, which is most common cause of emergency surgery in Western countries; challenges in correctly diagnosing appendicitis and possible symptoms for both children and adults discussed; appendectomy is only accepted treatment for appendicitis; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The appendix, a vestigial organ that people seem able to live very well without, is also one of the most distressing and costly parts of the human body.

docs.lead_paragraph: The birth rate among American girls ages 10 to 14 is at its lowest level since 1946. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the number of births dropped 38 percent from 1994 to 2002, even though the number of girls 10 to 14 climbed 16 percent. In 2002, the most recent year with complete data, there were 7,315 babies born to this age group, a rate of 0.7 live births per 1,000 females -- about the same as the rate nearly 60 years ago. The rate dropped among all racial groups, but it was higher for black and Hispanic girls than for white and Asian ones.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Fewer Young Girls Having Babies

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: The death of a California woman in January after she took an abortion pill prompted federal drug regulators on Monday to strengthen the warning label on the drug, RU-486, also known as mifepristone. The death was the third in the United States that the Food and Drug Administration has linked to the pill since its approval in 2000.

headline.main: F.D.A., Responding to a Third Death Linked to Abortion Pill, Strengthens a Warning Label

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration strengthens warning label on drug RU-486, also known as mifepristone, after linking it to death of California woman; abortion opponents say death demonstrates that drug is unsafe and should be withdrawn from market, but abortion rights advocates say it has been used by 360,000 US women and bad outcomes are exceptionally rare; drug's maker Danco Laboratories argues that death should not be attributed to RU-486, because coroner's report says woman had instead taken methotrexate, which is also used to induce abortion; death was third in United States that FDA has linked to RU-486 since its introduction in 2000 (M)
docs.snippet: Federal drug regulators strengthened the warning label on the pill, RU-486, after the death of a woman who took the pill.
